2.00.text: FutureMoneyTrends.com: Brazil Resources, Seizing the Opportunity.

5.10.text: BRI just announced an agreement to acquire Brazilian Gold Corp. which will triple their in ground gold resource,

10.40.text: The company is 35% institutionally owned with 16% of outstanding shares held by.

15.40.text: Doug Casey of Casey Research, Rick Rule of Sprott Assett Management, and Marin Katusa, a chief strategist for Casey Research.

22.00.text: The geological team has earlier discovered more than 10 million ounces of gold directly in Brazil

26.20.text: and is led by successful mining CEO Amir Adnani, who is currently on both the Fortune 40 and Casey NexTen list

40.50.text: FutureMoneyTrends.com: Greetings and thank you for joining us at FutureMoneyTrends.com.

42.50.text: I'm here at the Casey Summit with Jim Rickards. He's the author of Currency Wars.

47.50.text: He has a new book coming out as well. What is it called?

49.50.text: James Rickards: It's called The Death of Money: The Coming Collapse of the International Monetary System.

53.50.text: It'll be out in April; April 8th is the publication date. I finished writing it about a month ago and we're in editing.

59.50.text: It's a funny thing, Dan. We live in a world of what I call instant digital gratification, whether it's YouTube or Twitter,

67.50.text: everybody wants to put everything out there immediately, but a book is still an old-fashioned process.

71.50.text: It takes a year to write it and edit it and bind it, so it'll be out in April and I'll be talking more about it between now and then.

79.50.text: FutureMoneyTrends.com: It should be very interesting because I'm sure some of your analysis will have either been

82.50.text: proven right or proven wrong in the book, am I right?

84.50.text: James Rickards: Well, that's right, I mean it is forward-looking, so I say a lot of things in the book that I will be looking over in the years ahead, but sure.

93.50.text: It's something coming out in six months, it'll be a good test to see how things play out. We'll see if they play out as expected. That's exactly right.

100.50.text: FutureMoneyTrends.com: I've always wondered in the dollar crisis scenario if right on the cusp of the market just melting down and going crazy

109.50.text: that Obama and whatever Fed chairman of that time, say, next to him and they're instituting a gold standard.

115.50.text: Do you think it's possible that they, right before a major crisis is about to happen, they come in and switch the currency?

123.50.text: James Rickards: I don't think so. I think there are several scenarios: one is that we get to a gold standard by design.

127.50.text: In other words, people look at the system and they say that it really is not sustainable, it really is based on confidence,

133.50.text: but we're in the process of eroding confidence. There is no exit from quantitative easing.

138.50.text: We should say there's no good exit. You can back away from it, but then you'll implode the economy in a deflationary crash.

145.50.text: Or you can keep going and eventually cause a loss of confidence in the dollar and then have a hyper-inflationary crash, so you got a crash either way.

152.50.text: One looks like the Great Depression, one looks like the late '70s but worse.

156.50.text: Those are the only two paths, but there's no other path. There's no way we can just sort of taper, reduce it, finesse it, try to get growth on a self-sustaining path.

165.50.text: The reason for that is we're in a depression. And depressions are structural problems; they require structural solutions.

172.50.text: You cannot use a liquidity solution for a structural problem. You need a structural solution.

177.50.text: So there's nothing the Fed can do to solve the depression or to change the structural problems in the U.S. economy.

186.50.text: I mean, they're assuming, they're saying, "We're gonna print money until unemployment gets to 6 and a half percent."

191.50.text: Who says there's any relationship between printing money and unemployment? There's no necessary relationship there.

195.50.text: One's monetary, one's structural, so you need to do other things.

199.50.text: So therefore they're gonna keep going, but they think they're right.

202.50.text: I may be a critic and I may be able to point out why they're wrong, why their models are wrong and why this says "No Good Exit,"

209.50.text: but they think they're right and they're gonna keep going and kinda drive the bus over the cliff.

212.50.text: Now, at that point, when the crisis emerges, they may have to go to a gold standard.

217.50.text: They don't want to, but they may have to, to restore confidence.

221.50.text: But I'm very doubtful that they'll do it as a matter of choice and say,

224.50.text: "Look, we need to do this, let's just do it now, let's be honest, let's be transparent, let's be thoughtful."

231.50.text: You could do that but I think that's very unlikely.

234.50.text: FutureMoneyTrends.com: So in 20 years from now, do you think the world will look back and it will be the 2008 to whatever is going to be depression?

243.50.text: FutureMoneyTrends.com: Because nobody would ever say that it's a depression now, I mean you're saying it is and your analysis;

247.50.text: by the way, anybody who missed your speech, it's unfortunate because every word out of your mouth is backed by so much data and charts and statistics

256.50.text: so, ultimately you think people will look back at this time and everyone will acknowledge that it's a depression?

261.50.text: James Rickards: Oh, certainly. I mean, first of all I'd say it started in 2007.

264.50.text: 2008 was the panic and it was an emergency liquidity response to that, but the roots of this really go back to 2007.

271.50.text: That's when the sub-prime crisis erupted, that's when the Bear Stearns hedge funds melted down.

276.50.text: That's when the Fed first started in to cut the discount rate and respond a little bit, even though they were way behind the curve and didn't see it coming.

286.50.text: It could be over tomorrow if we had the right policies, but we don't have the right policies. It will continue indefinitely.

291.50.text: We look like Japan. Japan has said, people talk about the lost decade, we're in the third lost decade; it's been over 20 years

300.50.text: of depression, depressionary symptoms or depressionary economy in Japan.

305.50.text: The U.S. is now in the same mode, it's kind of ironic because for decades Bernanke and other scholars criticized the Japanese, saying,

313.50.text: "What's the matter with you guys, don't you know how to run monetary policy, don't you know how to get out of a depression?"

317.50.text: Then they said, you know, in 2007, "We are going to avoid the mistakes of Japan." But we've made every single mistake that Japan made.

324.50.text: We should have shut down banks in 2008. We didn't. We propped them up instead of shutting them down, which is exactly what the Japanese did.

330.50.text: They locked the problems into place and financed them instead of writing them off, shutting them down, putting backers in jail,

337.50.text: closing the banks, breaking the mob, stripping out the bad assets, putting them under a rock in trust for the American people,

343.50.text: sell them over 20 years or however long it takes. Then re-IPO the clean banks.

348.50.text: They didn't do that. Instead they did what the Japanese did, which is they propped up the system, they kept their buddies in place.

354.50.text: There was no real prosecutorial effort, and so we shouldn't be surprised that we have the same result as Japan, because we went down the same path structurally.

362.50.text: Now we printed more money than the Japanese did, but that's not the solution, so it's not going to work.

366.50.text: So having said all that, I just think that you will have this hyper-inflationary response at some point.

373.50.text: Not right away, because it's behavioral. The Fed needs to change behavior first.

377.50.text: But when they change it, they may find it spins out of control, as it did in the '70s.

382.50.text: At that point the price of gold will soar or, if we go into a depression

387.50.text: (I mean, we're in a depression, but if we go into a more severe deflationary mode),

392.50.text: the Fed may raise the price of gold as a way to create deflation. Either way, gold goes up in the end.

398.50.text: FutureMoneyTrends.com: You talked today about the helicopter money coming and that kind of excited me as someone who owns stocks in gold and silver.

404.50.text: Maybe it's because I feel comfortable where I live and stuff.

407.50.text: You know I'm not working in the inner city or something, but is that going to be really good for stocks when that helicopter money comes in?

417.50.text: James Rickards: Well, initially, this kind of inflationary environment is good for stocks,

421.50.text: but in the long way it's terrible for stocks. Inflation destroys capital formation.

426.50.text: The stock market is all about capital formation, earning profits, expanding your company, coming up with new companies,

434.50.text: capital formation, capital expansion, growth in earnings, growth in multiples.

438.50.text: That's what the stock market is about. Now initially, you have what's called money illusions.

443.50.text: So, a lot of money floods into the system, it chases assets, it could be housing, it could be a lot of things.

449.50.text: Stocks are part of it. No doubt the stocks have benefited the last four years from the Fed monetary ease.

454.50.text: Well, if you have more ease, the stock market should go higher.

457.50.text: Initially, but eventually the inflation outruns the gains and it turns out the gains are illusory.

462.50.text: It's not real and then the capital formation dries up, taxation goes up and the stock market crashes.

467.50.text: It's exactly what happened in the 1970s. We had a very severe, serious stock market crash in 1974

474.50.text: and then the stock market never achieved those highs again until sometime in the mid-1980s.

481.50.text: So you had a very long period of no growth in the stocks after a severe crash, and we'll have something similar.

487.50.text: FutureMoneyTrends.com: As far as rates going up, it would seem that if rates went up, that the government would look really bad

496.50.text: with the majority of the income going towards interest and then them borrowing even more.

502.50.text: Is it even possible; I mean are they going to just defend these low rates with everything they've got?

507.50.text: James Rickards: Sure. That's what financial repression is. That's what quantitative easing is.

511.50.text: Every time the rates want to go up, the Fed can just buy more bonds.

514.50.text: Of course, they buy bonds with printed money, but it just keeps the lid on rates.

518.50.text: I've spoken to people in the primary dealer community.

520.50.text: They're completely relaxed because they're just middle-men; they're intermediaries between the Fed and the banks; the institutional investors.

527.50.text: They buy bonds from the Treasury, they can finance them or sell them to the Fed or they can sell them to institutions.

533.50.text: So the primary dealer is basically the large banks are middle-men.

537.50.text: Now, the risk there is that they'll get caught out.

539.50.text: They've got long maturities, so they've got five-year notes or ten-year notes and they're financing them overnight in the repo market.

545.50.text: Well, what if the repo rate went up? All of a sudden the trade is profitable, it goes upside down, if the short-term rate gets above the long-term rate.

552.50.text: Or if long-term rates go up they have capital losses on the bonds.

556.50.text: So it's a very risky trade, but the Fed has told them, "We've got your back." That's what forward guidance is.

561.50.text: When the Fed says "We're not gonna raise rates for two years or three years, etc., then you can do the overnight financing for three years

568.50.text: and know that you're going to be paying zero rates."

570.50.text: So they've taken the risks out of the trade.

572.50.text: So the primary dealers are relaxed, the Fed is going to keep the lid on the interest rates.

576.50.text: You know, the only reason the interest rates went up over the summer was because of the taper talk.

580.50.text: But they didn't actually taper and I didn't expect them to and I honestly don't see how they're going to, maybe ever.

585.50.text: So the rates went up, not only in the fundamentals but because of the talk of tapering.

591.50.text: People were shocked, they said, "Wait a second, you're going to taper and do weak economic data? You're going to taper into a recession?"

596.50.text: Which is what they're doing. But they didn't taper, so now rates are coming back down again.

600.50.text: If we follow the Japan scenario, and I expect we will, I can see ten-year no-rates coming down to 80 basis points.

607.50.text: If they go from 250 to 80, that's the greatest bond market rally in history.

611.50.text: So everyone's worried about the bond bubble, but they're focused on nominal rates.

616.50.text: They're not looking at real rates.

618.50.text: Nominal rates could come down a lot more as a way of getting real rates lower, because inflation is low it may even dip into deflation.

624.50.text: So we could be set up. But in the long run rates would go way up and the country would go bankrupt and we'll all have hyper-inflation.

631.50.text: That could be two or three or four years away. Over the course of the next year you can see a very strong bond market rally.

637.50.text: FutureMoneyTrends.com: Do you think whatever's going to happen as far as a crisis or a restructuring structurally, is this going to happen within this decade?

646.50.text: James Rickards: Yeah, I would say a decade is a likely scenario.

648.50.text: You know, when you do the forecast, I drew it analytically, I used complexity theory, I used dynamic models and dynamic methodology.

656.50.text: So I look at how things play out and I recognize the fact that they could take several different paths.

660.50.text: I don't put a stake in the ground about one outcome. What I do is I look at several possible outcomes.

666.50.text: And even analysts who do that, they throw weights at them, they say,

669.50.text: "Well, there's a 20 percent chance of this and a 40 percent chance of this and then a 50 percent chance of this" or whatever.

675.50.text: What I say is "No, there's a 100 percent chance of one of them and a zero percent chance of all the others,

681.50.text: you just don't know ex-ante which one it's gonna be."

684.50.text: And so the art of analysis is really kind of getting the scenarios right.

688.50.text: Then identifying the milestones; identifying indications of warnings along the way.

694.50.text: When you see those indications and warnings emerge, then you can know that you're on this path instead of this path, so that's kind of how I look at the future.

701.50.text: So there are several possible outcomes but I think they end up with inflation, but you could have some deflation first.

709.50.text: So that's really difficult for investors, because things are kind of pulling two different directions.

714.50.text: FutureMoneyTrends.com: Yeah, it's been very frustrating for the gold investor.

716.50.text: You know, you look at all this, you see the crisis and you buy gold.

720.50.text: Yet gold for the last two years has gone down and it might even have further to go.

725.50.text: Do you have any perspective on why gold has been going down? Some say it's manipulation, some say it's just the market.

732.50.text: James Rickards: There are a number of reasons. There's certainly some Central Bank manipulation.

738.50.text: There's some fundamental reasons having to do with what we've been talking about, which is deflation.

741.50.text: Gold should go down in a deflation environment initially.

745.50.text: But if deflation gets bad enough, the government will make the price of gold go up because they get desperate to create inflation.

751.50.text: If you've tried everything, if you want inflation, and you've tried everything to create it, so you tried money printing, cutting rates, currency wars,

758.50.text: Operation Twist, QE, forward guidance, nominal GDP targeting, you've tried everything, you still didn't get the inflation.

766.50.text: There's one thing that always works, which is devaluing your currency against gold.

770.50.text: So there could come a time when deflation gets so bad that the Fed and the treasury actually raise the price of gold,

776.50.text: not to enrich gold investors, but to get close to generalized inflation.

781.50.text: Because if gold goes up, silver and oil will go up along with it. It's exactly what happened in 1933.

786.50.text: So that's one path. But the other, perhaps more likely path, is that the Fed just keeps printing money and finally succeeds in changing behavior,

795.50.text: velocity of the turnover money picks up and inflation goes up on its own.

799.50.text: Then gold will race way ahead of that. That'll just change the psychology.

802.50.text: My advice for gold investors today is to kind of do what the Chinese do: just buy the dips.

809.50.text: The Chinese bought a tonne, hundreds of tonnes of gold at the lows in July, July 2013.

816.50.text: Now, again, we had that smash in April and gold went down over 20 percent between April and June.

822.50.text: Well, right there at the end of June, the Chinese were buyers, so my advice to investors: don't use leverage.

828.50.text: Buy physical bullion. Don't buy paper gold. Do what the Chinese do, which is buy the dips, put it away and don't read the papers.

834.50.text: So gold's volatile. You just have to get used to it. And if gold is down a lot, it's because deflation has the upper hand.

841.50.text: But nothing moves in isolation. If gold traders down to, let's say, $800 an ounce, that is a highly deflationary world.

848.50.text: That probably means the stock market's crashing, other commodities are going down, so you might actually like your gold better in that environment,

855.50.text: because even though it went down a nominal space, it can outperform these other asset classes and still preserve wealth.

862.50.text: Of course, in the opposite case, if inflation takes off, we all know what's going to happen: gold is going to go way up.

867.50.text: FutureMoneyTrends.com: Yeah. What is your next book gonna be about? Or what is it about?

870.50.text: James Rickards: Well, it's both a prequel and a sequel to Currency Wars

873.50.text: in the sense that one of the parts of Currency Wars that people liked was the part about the war game.

880.50.text: The Pentagon, what they did in 2009, while there was some stuff, activity before that.

886.50.text: I talked about that really for the first time, so to kind of give the lead-up to that and how I would've gotten involved in that war game

893.50.text: with the Pentagon, etcetera, so I hope that's interesting to readers.

896.50.text: But then the sequel is to kind of go into the future.

898.50.text: With Currency Wars it was a lot of the economic history. And I thought that was very important.

902.50.text: First of all, readers like it, they enjoy economic history, but it's also educational.

905.50.text: And if you want to talk about gold, if you jump right into gold, a lot of people go,

910.50.text: "Oh, you're a gold bug, you're a gold nut," or whatever, they don't take it seriously.

913.50.text: But if you can explain it over an 150-year period and how gold was always in the monetary system and the role it played,

920.50.text: then the reader comes along with you and they're much more interested in it, more attentive to it when your actually get to it in the present-day context.

927.50.text: So the new book won't have as much history, because that's in Currency Wars and you don't need to do it twice.

932.50.text: It's more forward-leaning, talking about the future of the international monetary system.

937.50.text: FutureMoneyTrends.com: I'll never forget that part, because your book was like reading a novel.

939.50.text: And then that part where you were, your proposal was that the Russians back it with gold with China, I believe, and then it was on Drudge the next;

948.50.text: well, first people blew you off, and then it was on Drudge the next day.

951.50.text: James Rickards: Well, that's right. An even better validation: We did this in 2009.

955.50.text: We were; the Harvard eggheads all laughed at us and they said,

957.50.text: "Yeah, gold has no role in the monetary system, you guys don't know what you're talking about."

961.50.text: And of course, it was on Drudge the next day.

963.50.text: That was right around the time that Putin and later the Chinese and the BRICS started being more vociferous, really standing up to the United States.

970.50.text: But since we did that, we came up with this scenario in 2009 that the Russians and Chinese would buy gold and move away from the dollars

978.50.text: to gold reserve currency through some means. Well, since then the Russians have increased their gold reserves by over 60 percent.

986.50.text: They've gone from 600 tonnes to over 1000 tonnes, almost 70 percent.

991.50.text: The Chinese have increased their gold reserves by a multiple; we don't know how much because they're not transparent about it,

996.50.text: but they clearly have some number: 3,000, 4,000 tonnes, the exact number's not known, but it's kind of that order of magnitude up from 1000 tonnes.

1005.50.text: So the Chinese have increased their gold 300 or 400 percent, the Russians have increased their gold almost 70 percent.

1010.50.text: They're acting exactly the way we told the Pentagon in 2009, so I think that was pretty good vindication for our scenario.

1017.50.text: FutureMoneyTrends.com: On the treasury front, are the Chinese still big buyers of treasuries?

1023.50.text: James Rickards: No, they're actually reducing their purchases. Now, they're not dumping them.

1026.50.text: This idea that suddenly they're going to dump two trillion dollars of treasury. That's not gonna happen.

1032.50.text: Because it would be too disruptive; they would shoot themselves in the foot.

1035.50.text: They would crash the market, the U.S. could actually freeze their treasury accounts.

1039.50.text: People don't realize that, but the president has the legal authority to freeze the Chinese accounts.

1044.50.text: We wouldn't have to steal their money, just say, "Hey, we're freezing it. We'll get back to you later about when you can collect."

1049.50.text: You gotta get back to them and make good behaviors, so to speak.

1052.50.text: And the Chinese know that, so they're not gonna go there because the U.S. has very powerful tools to preserve its interests and preserve its markets.

1060.50.text: But at the margin, as they get more reserves, as they run a continuing current accounts surplus, they get direct foreign investments.

1069.50.text: They get their hands on more dollars. They don't have to invest new dollars in treasuries.

1073.50.text: What they're doing is swapping it for Euros, they're investing very heavily in Europe, they're buying direct assets,

1079.50.text: they're buying mines, they're buying companies, buying stocks, etc.

1083.50.text: So they're not dumping what they have, but they've slowed down the purchases.

1087.50.text: They're selling a little, and most importantly, at the margin they're diversifying into other assets.

1092.50.text: That's going to put a lot of pressure on U.S. interest rates, because in the past the Chinese have been buyers, so the question is:

1099.50.text: Who's going to step in and fill the void, so to speak, as what's called "the buyer of last resort" of treasury? Well, the answer, of course, is the Fed.

1107.50.text: FutureMoneyTrends.com: Yeah. In closing, I know in a previous discussion we had, you said Obamacare was a revenue-raiser.

1113.50.text: What about on the economic front? Because there's two major things I'm seeing: the companies are reducing people to 28 hours, 28-29 hours.

1120.50.text: And then some employers with over 50 employees are reducing it to 49. This seems like a very common-sense thing for any employer.

1128.50.text: You're obviously, you're not gonna put yourself in a situation where you're gonna crush all your profits.

1133.50.text: What does this mean for the economy? I mean, is this just gonna make things rapidly deteriorate?

1138.50.text: James Rickards: Yes. I mean, when I said Obamacare is a revenue-raiser, I didn't mean it as a good thing.

1142.50.text: What I meant is that it's a hidden tax. Basically we're gonna tax the economy directly and indirectly and that was a very bad thing.

1149.50.text: But all of the other aspects you mentioned, Dan, which are maybe I'm gonna call them unintended consequences,

1155.50.text: maybe some of them were actually intended, but yeah.

1157.50.text: We're going from full-time jobs to part-time jobs, we're going from expanding work forces to,

1162.50.text: if you have 49 employees you have no interest in hiring one more employee.

1166.50.text: So we're taking the most entrepreneurial, small-to-medium-sized enterprises in the country, we're capping out the number of people they're going to hire,

1173.50.text: to the extent they're going to hire more people who are part-time.

1176.50.text: It is a huge tax on the economy. It's creating all kinds of inefficiencies, so sure.

1181.50.text: The economy has enough problems as it is. I mentioned before that a depression is a structural problem, so you need structural solutions.

1189.50.text: This is, Obamacare is actually adding to the structural problem. Not only is it not a solution, it makes the structural problem worse.

1197.50.text: FutureMoneyTrends.com: Yeah. It's very scary and it's very sad.

1200.50.text: FutureMoneyTrends.com: Mr. Rickards, thank you so much. I hope everyone checks out Currency Wars and your next book in April.

1205.50.text: If someone wants to follow you, how can they; do you have a website?

1208.50.text: James Rickards: I don't have a website, but the best way is on Twitter.

1211.50.text: My Twitter handle is at JamesTRickard. R-I-C-K-A-R-D-S, so, @jamestrickards,

1217.50.text: and I put out a steady stream of commentary on the economy, the Fed, and the international monetary system.

1223.50.text: Sometimes I talk about baseball. I hope people can follow along and enjoy it.

1228.50.text: FutureMoneyTrends.com: Real quickly, I almost forgot to ask, because he's gonna be really mad if I don't ask you about Bitcoin.

1233.50.text: FutureMoneyTrends.com: I'll just throw it out there: Bitcoin, what are your thoughts?

1236.50.text: James Rickards: It's one of my least favorite topics because I'm very skeptical of Bitcoin, but Bitcoin supporters are fanatical, they love it.

1242.50.text: So every time I say something mildly negative about it I get a lot of; I hear from the Bitcoin people, so to speak.

1249.50.text: But I will say, I was down in California about four months ago. I was in a debate on Bitcoin.

1255.50.text: Look, I've got nothing against the technology. I've actually read the technical papers. I've spoken to a lot of people about it.

1260.50.text: It is cool technology, it's good encryption.

1263.50.text: The block chain method of validating, the fact that it's decentralized and dispersed.

1269.50.text: You can fire a drone missile at a Bitcoin server and it doesn't matter because there's

1272.50.text: another one over here that's got the block chain and they can validate.

1275.50.text: So, I understand all that and it's cool stuff and it does attract libertarians and it does attract technophiles.

1282.50.text: So I get all that, but what I said at the time was, "Don't deceive yourself, don't kid yourself, don't think the government's not watching."

1288.50.text: This idea that somehow you're escaping government scrutiny, or you're outside the government matrix or whatever is just not true.

1296.50.text: And that has been validated since I made those remarks.

1299.50.text: There's been a number of, Mt. Gox, you know, was attacked by the government.

1303.50.text: And of course there's Silk Road, and now arrests have been made.

1306.50.text: So, the government's watching everything you do, so if you're in Bitcoin enjoy it but don't kid yourself, don't think the government's not watching.

1313.50.text: FutureMoneyTrends.com: Thank you so much for your time.
